comments.commentBody:
I understand this is a common mindset in the US where used cars tend to be trashed

but in Oz I've read the average age of cars was like 10yo - my current car is a 1991 Honda Civic I bought when it was 12 years old in as-new condition (driven by an old guy on Sundays) for 1/5th of the new price - I've now had it for over 13 years and it runs perfectly (I don't drive much - I mostly walk) - just checked - I've done maybe 50,000km(30,000 miles) in 13 years so not much - but I've no reason to dump it while it continues to tick like a watch and be totally reliable.

wow - so you're saying - I should go and live in India, wear a sarong/dhoti, go to Kumbh Mela - and live naked in a forest hut, while begging for alms or maybe getting free coconuts and mangos from the forest trees ?

I'd think about it - but I hate the hot weather - I'm a chocolate - much nicer at pleasantly cool temperatures.

There's a saying I once heard, a long time ago. I'm going to paraphrase because I don't remember the exact words. "Be sparce with advice. The fools won't listen and the wise don't need it". Having lived to age 70, I'll leave it at that.
I do floss - but my partner still complains about my bad breath - she say it's caused by my drinking lotsa coffee and not enough water

my first paid job was at 13 - I recently retired at 63

I enjoyed my work - loved teaching - just not the mindless endless busywork nightmare of administrative details demanded by seat-polishers in upper management looking for their KPIs to get their bonuses.

Now retired, I enjoy every day - my previous job is like a distant memory - and I'm having fun doing whatever I feel like.

Mind you - I have many hobbies and interests I have developed and maintained for many years - paid employment was just a distraction and hindrance to my further involvement in the things I enjoy - now I'm FREE to do what I like, when I like !
Some workers pay into state retirement plans instead of SSA (e.g., teachers in California).  I assume that's what Frenchy is talking about

I enjoy NOT spending money - the frugalist pleasure of the bargain hunt and saving money

however this may be because I grew up upper middle class and always had enough if we managed carefully - a sign of the middle class

I understand that some who grew up poor - and never had enough - can tend to spend any windfall on a splash-out party as they never know when they'll have money again - and they want to show others in their community a good time to return any help they may have got from others in tough times

so careful saving may not be in the mindset of folk like those who grew up poor

obviously there will be some - maybe upper working class - to whom saving is a goal - but I've read maybe the lower working class tend to be all about splash the cash and party like it's 1999 - like there's no tomorrow !
I'm 25. I'd love to save for retirement, but every dollar I make is accounted for. I suspect that that, not lack of knowledge or desire, is why more people my age don't save.

It is very hard to save with student loans and adult responsibilities and salaries that often fall short.
Try changing something fundamental - try shared housing, get a second job for a few months to get ahead on savings, go on a cash-only period to make a dent in credit card balances... Something that is for you out of the box and changes the financial dynamic for a limited period.

Well I haven't retired yet, but as someone who was laid off twice once they turned 55, plan to be able to retire (or make do) at 55.  Save at least 10% of your income, skip the Starbucks and the material status symbols.  It won't make you happy anyway.  Invest in relationships, experiiences, index funds and stay away from shallow people and corporations that suck the life out of you.
Stop patronizing businesses that exploit labor, organize, and become politically active.

I was really disappointed by this piece.  "Banal" (as described by another reader)  is a truly accurate description of what these aspiring "writers" gleaned from their interviews. There was much insight to be had, but if a single one of them gained any perhaps it was "edited" out.  Very superficial.

No human being is "illegitimate".

let me explain, when a child is without a father it is a disaster in every way. That includes financially in terms of development, etc, etc. This is the reason that illegitimacy was so stigmatized in the past. It proved a disaster, not something to celebrate as you do.

All these comments about save, save, save depressed the heck out of me.
It's gotten so that I'm afraid to spend $1 for a cup of coffee at the bodega because I should save, save, save.

If it is a (banal) recurring theme, then hint hint... unfortunately it is a recurring theme for many people that they wish they had saved more -
The takeaway is seek enjoyment and balance - but it helps to be financially aware and save.
Have a great retirement (when the time comes)

The older you get, the less scary the idea of death becomes.

My dad advised, Get a job with a pension, a government job. I am so glad that I now have a NYS pension even though I'm now teaching elementary school math, a career I began one year following retirement. It's the most fun job I've ever had! I intend to stay as long as I can walk, talk, and remember my times tables.

All these comments and advice are all a waste of time. There are no formulas for success in life. None! It's all about luck. Many sacrifice, save their money, and then get sick when old and can't enjoy their money and then they die. While they are saving their money, bankers enjoy making money with their money and living it up. Then, after death, others inherit their money, some who didn't even care about them, and then enjoy the money earned by others and spend it! Some spend their money while young and enjoy life when they can and are healthy. They end up broke but many times, happy with all the great memories. Whether you rent or buy a house, it's the same money spent. Renting allows for mobility, but owning a house gives you the freedom to live with peace and quiet and decorating it the way you want. Marriage: some meet a compatible person and some don't. Kids: some have kids who bring joy to their lives and some don't. Those who claim to have a formula are just clueless. Just do what you can and hope for the best.

I am not retired yet, but I am in my late 50's and getting closer to reaching that milestone. As I have gotten older and yes, wiser, I have come to realize the great importance of living beneath your means, getting a good education or learning a useful trade, and investing the time and effort to take care of your health and your relationships with the people you love.

What young people know is that people need to stick together to protect themselves. Being in my 60's I believe that working people need strong unions to protect themselves. From what I've seen recently, I believe young people are in agreement. In solidarity there is strength!

Several
-Try many things, other music, other dance, other food
-Don't waste time on TV, have regular nights with friends at home and volunteer
-Take care of your health plus lots of exercise and health includes teeth
-Lads, pick a lassie by her strengths and prudence, they last longer. Meet her while volunteering
-Have only one child, the world is crowded
-Save and spend on doing not flash
-Hand make many things in your life from food to furniture to cloths to gardens
-Read non fiction and classic literature, it will save you time. People came before us.

When we bought our last house (our third) in our mid-forties, we picked up a nice $180K ranch in a wonderful neighborhood close to campus in our clean and safe midwestern city and paid it off in ten years. Together my wife and I had the income to buy a $400K McMansion but didn't need an enormous castle and despised the ostentatiousness of those soulless behemoths and the pretentious people who often occupy them. Saving all that extra mortgage money, and some other smart planning (and a bit of unplanned luck) allowed my wife and I to retire in our mid-fifties. Even though we both enjoyed our respective careers, we like being free much, much better! One other tip: avoid the downward-spiraling trap of consumerism and the debt it often brings. Rule of thumb about "stuff:" If you don't have it already, it's likely you don't need it.

The title of this article is not reflective of the statements shown.

The comments section, however, correctly addresses the title.

Oh please. Many many single women - either divorced or single-by-choice - will never be able to retire, especially under Trump's benevolence. I tell younger people (to whom I teach writing) to forget about the future and fight for economic justice now.  The Times needs to start interviewing he big chunk of us old people who have lived as counter-culture workers and activists for decades.
Plus one to that!

Advice ---
Remember to look everywhere for political corruption and take part in getting your share.
Remember to put excessive amounts of laundered cash in island countries to live in Republican luxury in your old age.
Remember to purchase you wealthy people's cave/hideaway or whatever they're called to survive the destruction of the planet by global warming deniers.
Remember to purchase many cans of Chef Boyardee spaghetti.
Remember not to consume your loved ones no matter how grim things get.
Remember to start building your weapons arsenal now --- motto--- bigger the better.
Remember to make some swastika stencils for your car.
Remember most of all to try to get older. Sort of...

agreed - I bristled everyday with cockroaches in my stomach with a boss who barked like a dog to me like a cat - hair standing on end.

We parted ways and I grabbed the next job that I saw - which turned out to be teaching - complete opposite work conditions - from flexible to fixed hours - from flexible to fixed holidays - from sitting at a desk all day to standing most of the day - from rarely talking to talking most of the day - from little communication with others to constant communication with others - from a toxic boss to a lovely boss - in fact I'm going back to see them soon !

So yes - if you hate it - change ! Cortisol/stress hormone will burn you up and I just read shrinks your muscles and builds fat - you don't want that - dump the stress by quitting things you hate !

Get political. Now. We tried to change the world, but failed to undo the mess we were left by the "greatest" generation. Stay on top of what laws are passed and who gets into office. They are threatening to gut the social safety net and our healthcare costs are already obscene, which matters greatly as you age. And I know everyone will tell you to scrimp and save. My husband and I did that. The "great recession" hit and we were laid off in our late 50s. Then he developed a brain tumor suddenly and dies within a year ... costing us half of what was left of our savings. Our culture doesn't value age and treats older people as so much nuisance instead of recognizing that we don't become raging useless idiots because we are over 50. YOU will eventually be over 50. You may become "un-hireable" and have to scramble financially. Make sure you elect leaders who will pass laws that help you and your families through the worst of times. That's what all those taxes you're paying in throughout your younger years are supposed to go toward. Don't give in to the illusion that YOU will be different ... you won't hit bad times, you won't need help, you are prepared. Remember, not everyone suffering through having to work into their 70s or live in squalor squandered their money or made bad decisions. Our circumstances are greatly affected by those in power. Vote like your lives depend on it. Someday they will.

ow - health is number one - as the guy said in the video - all the money in world is no use if you don't have your health.

A work colleague was always exercising - a fitness nut - yet was always complaining of their latest injury - torn ligament, shoulder dislocation - I was 'um - if it keeps hurting you - why don't you stop doing it ?' - I guess they enjoyed the dopamine (exercise feel good hormone) high.
